Award.AwardTitle: Multiphase Chemistry and Mass Transport in Submicron Mixed Inorganic and Organic Aerosol Particles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) program of the Division of Chemistry and the Atmospheric Chemistry program of the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences will support the research program of Prof. Joel Thornton of the University of Washington. Professor Thornton and his students will study the reactivity of N2O5 in small aerosol particles and how it depends upon particle size and morphology when moderately soluble organic carbonaceous material is mixed with inorganic salts in aqueous solution droplets. N2O5 reacts primarily on liquid or solid particles suspended in air (aerosol particles) that range in size from 10 nanometers to 1 micrometer. Understanding chemical reactivity in such small spatial domains is of fundamental importance beyond interpreting atmospheric composition. The study will make use of state of the art mass spectrometry and particle sizing instruments, and involve collaboration with researchers at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL).

The proposed research will improve our understanding of the fundamental length scales of chemical reactions, of interest generally to the physical and environmental chemistry communities, and provide reaction rate measurements on atmospherically relevant particles. The latter is critical for developing robust parameterizations of gas-particle reactions for use in air quality and coupled chemistry-climate models that ultimately inform regulatory policy. The project will provide excellent training opportunities to students, including to members of under-represented groups, who wish to pursue a professional scientific career in an area of great societal importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the impact of human-induced emissions of pollutants to the atmosphere requires a detailed understanding of the physics and chemistry which govern their transformations and transport. This award allowed us to probe the fundamental physical chemistry governing the reactions of atmospheric pollutants that occur in the condensed-phases of suspended airborne particulate matter, known as aerosol particles. Specifically, we aimed to understand how the phase, morphology, composition, and size of atmospheric particles affected the removal of a key reservoir of nitrogen oxides. 

We created an experimental apparatus to probed the fundamental length scale over which N2O5 enters a nanoparticle droplet and diffuses or reacts to form nitrate - a major component of wintertime pollution haze and a cause of ecosystem eutrophication. We used this apparatus to show that organic carbonaceous material in particles, which arises from fossil fuel combustion or natural vegetative emissions, can phase separate and form a coating over the aqueous solution component and thereby greatly slow the reaction of N2O5, which requires liquid water. We also showed that chloride in particles, from sea spray or coal combustion, can increase the rate of reaction so much that N2O5 diffuses in the droplet barely a few nanometers before it reacts away. In contrast, other more component particle components such as sulfates from coal combusion are not as reactive and the N2O5 diffusions 30 - 40 nanometers before reacting. This long length scale leads to a nonlinear dependence of N2O5 reactions on particle size, which varies from 10 nanometers to 10,000 nanometers. 

The insights and fundamental parameters we obtained from our studies can be used to improve the ability of computer models of air quality and atmospheric chemistry to more accurately replicate the fate of these key pollutants which affect urban smog formation and the self-cleansing ability of the atmosphere which in turn affects the lifetime of greenhouse gases such as methane. We have reported our results in peer-reviewed journal articles, one is completely open-access, and the other is available at most major university libraries around the world.

The project involved the training of three women, a postdoctoral fellow, a graduate student, and undergradate research assistant in state-of-the-art measurement technology and experimental apparatus construction, data analysis software, and manuscript writing.
